Cannot parse .xml file containing information about keyboard kits. Try removing application data in system settings. \n\nError: %s

\t\tThere are many useful features in this app, which are initially \"invisible\". That\'s why we\'ve created a special window — \"Tips\". \n\t\tYou can open the tips right now or firstly have a look at the app and read them later. \n\t\t\"Tips\" can be open by clicking at three dots in the upper right corner.
The kit was unpacked moments ago
You should take a look at the default kit as there may be new cool features
Sorry, but new keyboards kits cannot be saved by unknown reason. Here are some details. Please, send screenshot of this window to RootTemplate. We would be grateful if you could do this.
Would you like to check for updates?
This fraction is approximately equal to result number and differs from it by %1$s%%.

Unfortunately, you cannot edit the button set that is available by default. You need to create a new set by choosing \"New kit\" from the menu at the top of the screen.
Advanced settings are no longer displayed, but their values are not deleted. You can get back to editing by turning them on again.
Changes will be applied after exiting the settings.

resources.string: \tHaving read all the tips, you\'ll know all features of this application. \n\tNow click on \"Forward\" button in the upper right corner to continue.

\tIn the background you see one of the pages with buttons. One of — there are plenty of them! You can scroll the pages by swiping your finger left or right. \n\tTry to scroll the pages here, in this window, using two buttons below.
\tSome buttons, as it may seem at first, mean exactly the same things. \n\tAbout these buttons on the following pages.
Orange (or blue in dark theme) button calculates entered expression and outputs the result to input field.
Grey button appends \"=\" symbol into expression. \n\nThis may be used to declare a variable or a function. Read more on this in the following pages.
Used in scientific notations. Read more about it later (again).
This is Euler\'s number, approximately equal to 2.718.
A comma splits function arguments. Example: \"f(x,y)=x^y\", \"f(4.5,6)\".
A point is a decimal mark.
\tOur app uses some non-standard operators, that\'s why we put here a table with operator precedence (precedence decreases from top to bottom).
\tLog function can take one or two input variable(s) (also known as arguments). \n\n\tIf only one argument is passed, then log(n) returns natural logarithm of the input:
\tIf two arguments are passed, then log(b, n) returns base-b logarithm of n.
\tAn example with two inputs. In what power 2 (this will be the first argument) is necessary to raise to get 8 (and this\'ll be the second)?
\tIf you can\'t remember the order of arguments, use a phrase from the paragraph above.

Like log, root function also can take one or two arguments. 

	By default, i.e. with a single argument, the √ function returns a square root of the input. 

	If the second argument is passed, then √(a, n) function returns a-th root of n. 
	For example:
\tOnce again, if you cannot remember the order of arguments, use the phrase: \"Take the fourth root (the first argument) of 16 (the second argument)\".
\tNaN (Not a Number) is a special value of a number. It is generated as a result of, e.g., dividing 0 by 0. Any operation (addition, subtraction, division) by NaN produce NaN.

\tUsually, when you press the button (I mean the ones in the background), exactly that character is added into the input field, that is written on the button. However, some buttons, if they aren\'t released for a time, could add the character not in lower but in the upper case. \n\tThis may be used for, let\'s say, adding a new variable, e.g. constant G in physics, not to be confused with the other variable — g (gravitational acceleration). Variable names are case sensitive! \n\tTry it now. Initially, simply click on the button. Then hold it down.

\t\"History\" window consists of records, each of which contains one calculation. If you click on a entry, a context menu will be open, main actions of which would be to copy the expression or the result or to paste them into the input field. \n\tTry it now. Press on a button below. If history is currently empty, then the program will automatically add a few records.
\tBy the way, history can be opened from the options menu that appears after clicking on three dots in the upper right corner in the background.

\tThis page is just a reminder that if you want something to change, check, whether it is possible to change in the settings. \n\tDo you need to view typed variables, change the period of storing the history or enable digit grouping — open the settings!

\tPages (in the background) are designed as follows: there is a home page and \"side\" pages. The home page opens immediately after the application is launched. \n\t\"Side\" pages can automatically return to home: (1) after a button is clicked, (2) return after a button is double clicked or (3) do not return al all. \n\tFor instance, the left page (with the letters of the Latin/Greek alphabets) will return you to the home page after double clicking on any button there.
\t\"E\" is used for presenting numbers in scientific notation and means \"…times ten raised to the power of…\", or \"… × 10^…\". Here are some examples:
\tThis notation is often used to presenting very large or very small numbers. E.g. this is how proton mass can be written in kilograms:
You can find out more at Wikipedia.
\tA namespace is where all typed variables and functions are written and stored. \n\tVariables and functions can be declared as follows:
\tPlease note: all variable/function names are always written at the left, and what they equal to is written at the right. \n\tFunctions can be used like this:

\tIn practice the variables are usually used for storing constants (usually physical). For instance, if you had enough typing masses of elementary particles, their charges and so on each time. Variables can also be used as a replacement for classic memory (MC, MR, M+, M−).

You can convert non-integer numbers from decimals (0.6666667) to fractions (2/3). 

	Once you have calculated entered expression and got a fraction answer, hold on the expression to open a standard "Copy / Paste" menu and click on corresponding item ("As fraction"). 

	Attention! If you try to convert a decimal with a very large denominator or even irrational, the app will output an approximately equal fraction. Try to do this with a pi number!
Now you know everything about the app
